text: The word for BORING or BORED is ABURRIDO, ABURRIDO, ABURRIDO, A-B-U-R-R-I-D-O, ABURRIDO.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now, this is BORING or BORED.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: One of these words in English is a characteristic, another one is a state.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: BORING, if I say you are BORING, is it a state or a characteristic?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And if I say you are BORED, is it a state or a characteristic?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So in English we have two different words to express this difference.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Whereas in Spanish, you will just decide whether you are going to use SER or ESTAR.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, you will have to think about it.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How will you say, IT IS BORING?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: HE IS BORED, is it a characteristic or a state?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Spanish is more subtle than that.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So with some adjectives, we get a different meaning, depending on whether we use SER or ESTAR.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: The word for FROM in Spanish is DE.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We get this forming part of many Latin English words.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: The DE of DELIVER is actually FROM.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: LIVER is to do with freedom, like LIBERACIÓN.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How would you say TO LIBERATE?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So again, we see this grey area between V and B, between English and Spanish.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Between LIBRE and LIVER and DELIVER.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Just as we did between SAVE and SABER, for example.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So DELIVER is like FROM or OF FREEING, which has much more sense if you look at the original meanings of DELIVER, like TO DELIVER A BABY, DELIVER ME FROM EVIL, rather than TO DELIVER A PACKAGE, which is a much more modern meaning.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You can see much more the ideology in the vocabulary with the other uses.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Another interesting word that we can see this DE in English is DECIPHER, for example.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: DECIPHER is actually a combination of Arabic and Latin.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You have DE meaning OF or FROM, and CIPHER from SAFRA, which means ZERO in Arabic.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So to decipher is to go from zero or something like this.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So anyway, we have DE for FROM or OF.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now, if I want to ask where is he from, is it a characteristic or a state where you are from?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Yes, it's not where you are, it's where you are from.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So in Spanish, we're going to say, From where are you?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And you informal, you remember how is you are?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: It's kind of similar to ES.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So this sentence actually will help you remember this kind of irregular form, eres, because you will hear it all the time.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How would you say, where are they from?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But if you want to ask where are they, their location, where are they, how would you ask?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Because now we refer to a state.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So we have this adjective as well, libre, like in deliver, liberation, libre, which means free.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Again, we might mean a state or we might mean characteristic.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now, sometimes, to show the difference, we might not just use ser and estar, we might actually also change the way we say it.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So for example, if you want to say I am free, and you mean from your exams, from work, do you think you mean a state or a characteristic?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So how would you say that?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And libre does not change for masculine and feminine because it ends i.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Only adjectives ending o would change.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now, if you mean as a characteristic, as a characteristic of your personality, you are a free person, then you might say...
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You might also say I am a free person.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And you could say I am a...
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Persona is feminine, not because of you, but because the word is feminine.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So I, as a male, would also say...
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So it's the noun in itself, persona, that is feminine.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So in this case, with libre, there's no problem to move between ser and estar.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You can use libre with ser or with estar to give slightly different meanings.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So some adjectives you will be able to move between ser and estar, and others you won't.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: If you want to get around that uncertainty, instead of trying out soy libre, you could just say soy una persona libre.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And then, because persona is going with soy, because what you are saying, in fact, is I am a person, soy una persona, then you know you're safe.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Also, different Spanish dialects can have different ideas about what should go with ser and what should go with estar.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, for example, casado, which means married, not cansado, casado, comes from casa, literally means housed.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: When you're married, you are housed.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Casado, in some places they use with ser, in some places they use with estar.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: They can't agree on whether being married is a characteristic or a state.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: If you want to avoid this insecurity about it, you can say soy una persona casada.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And then you know that persona is going with soy, so whatever then describes persona is not important.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: When you say I am a person, then that is characteristic.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Let's explore this idea a little more.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How would you say I am busy?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Or I would say estoy ocupado.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now, if I want to say I'm a busy person, then with this adjective, actually, I can't switch to soy and say soy ocupado.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But you, as a Spanish learner, how are you supposed to know that?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So you can use persona as a safety net in the sense of I am a busy person, and then you're sure it's perfect Spanish.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So how would you say I am a busy person?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So that's a characteristic, because what you're actually saying is I am a person, and much more characteristic than that you can't get.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So estoy ocupado as a state, and then soy una persona ocupada characteristic.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Males or females would say persona ocupada.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Ocupada refers to persona, not to the speaker.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So I would also say soy una persona ocupada.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How would you say we are busy?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: But if you wanted to say we are busy people...
speaker: Speaker 1

text: To be worried is to be preoccupied.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So how do you think that would sound?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: He is worried as a characteristic.
speaker: Speaker 1
